text.*:
Audubon Plantation House
U.S. National Register of Historic Places
Show map of Louisiana
Show map of the US
Location 21371 Hoo Shoo Too Road, Baton Rouge, Louisiana
Coordinates 30°21′05″N 90°57′20″W﻿ / ﻿30.35134°N 90.95549°W﻿ / 30.35134; -90.95549Coordinates: 30°21′05″N 90°57′20″W﻿ / ﻿30.35134°N 90.95549°W﻿ / 30.35134; -90.95549
Area 2.25 acres (0.91 ha)
Built c.1850
Architectural style Greek Revival
NRHP reference # 87000729[1]
Added to NRHP May 14, 1987

The Audubon Plantation is a Southern plantation with a historic mansion located at 21371 Hoo Shoo Too Road, Baton Rouge, Louisiana.

The house was completed in c.1850 but origins of Audubon plantation remains quite obscure. A reference to Audubon can be found in the Statement of the Sugar Crop for 1892. At that time the plantation owner was Octavius Bullion, while the mansion was rented to Dixon family.[2][3]

The house was listed on the National Register of Historic Places on May 14, 1987.[1]

See also[edit]

  • National Register of Historic Places listings in East Baton Rouge Parish, Louisiana

References[edit]

  1. ^ a b National Park Service (2013-11-02). "National Register Information System". National Register of Historic Places. National Park Service. 
  2. ^ "Audubon Plantation House" (PDF). State of Louisiana's Division of Historic Preservation. Retrieved May 5, 2018.  with two photos and two maps
  3. ^ National Register Staff (February 1987). "National Register of Historic Places Inventory/Nomination Form: Audubon Plantation House". National Park Service. Retrieved May 5, 2018.  With eight photos from 1987.
